Ron,
I doubt that these  images start as presentations of specific swords.=
 They
look for like summary interpretations of what ALL the swords in the
c=
ategory should look - and 'feel'  - like. Plus they do not appear to use
te=
chniques of traditional Japanese graphics. A side-by-side comparison of a
p=
icture and a sword would be wonderful, but I'd really like to see one of
th=
ese pictures being made. It is almost as if they are drawn from memory
base=
d on a deeper understanding that a single sword could convey.
They sure are=
 wonderful
PBleed


Jim, all -

I bet it would be interesting to see oshiga=
ta presented side-by-side of the
very same sword, using Nagayama's method (=
which apparently illustrates
details in a very graphic way) and the traditi=
onal (realist) method.  One
method "draws in" the detail that should be not=
ed while the other method
gives a very "true" illustration of the hamon, le=
aving finding and
understanding the subtle "detail" up to the viewer...some=
thing like that,
anyway.

Ron
STL

  Tom,
  Any =
idea of how the oshigata are actually drawn?  Looks like mottled gray
paper=
, the usual ink cake for the outline... opaque white pigment
(gouache?) for=
 the hamon?  Not sure how the hada is drawn in other than by
lots of sharp =
pencil work.  Interesting way of representing utsuri and
antai.  Reality ca=
n be marked on paper in many different ways.  I wonder if
Nagayama-sensei's=
 methods will catch on.  Certainly different.

  Jim
